discussion.content: B. a 12-MB bitmap file. A similar question was asked in Topic 3 question 39.

questions.answer_description:
Unrecognized file formats are excluded from the search.
Certain types of files, such as Bitmap or MP3 files, don't contain content that can be indexed. As a result, the search indexing servers in Exchange and SharePoint don't perform full-text indexing on these types of files. These types of files are considered to be unsupported file types.
Incorrect Answers:
A: DOCX is a supported Microsoft PowerPoint file format.
C: RTF is a supported Rich Text File format.
D: PPTX is a supported Microsoft PowerPoint file format.
Note:
There are several versions of this question in the exam. The question has two possible correct answers:
1. a 5-MB MP3 file
2. a 12-MB BMP file
Other incorrect answer options you may see on the exam include the following:
1. a 10-MB XLSX file
2. a 100-MB VSDX file
3. a 75-MB PDF file
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/partially-indexed-items-in-content-search?view=o365-worldwide https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/securitycompliance/export-a-content-search-report

There is no 'View Resultsג€ option. You can preview results but that will only show up to 100 emails. To guarantee you're getting all results, you'll need to export them to a PST file.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/limits-for-content-search

discussion.content: still valid, it was in my exam last Feb 5, 2022
Correct answer is D: view result/preview results.

Correct answer is B
Explanation : After you run a search, the number of content locations and an estimated number of search results are displayed on the search flyout page. You can quickly view statistics, such as the content locations that have the most items that match the search query. After you run a search, you can preview the results or export them to a local computer.

I have tested this today and can confirm that after running this, I was given the option to Export report (A) or Export results (B).

Export results (B) appears to provide more information so I will go with B.

In the following article there's an option to preview search results, but it's just a sampling. Question didn't say preview it said view the results. Answer B, export results, is correct.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/content-search?view=o365-worldwide#next-steps

comments.content:
"A maximum of 100 items from a single content location (a mailbox or a site) can be previewed. This means that it's possible that less than 1,000 items might be available for preview. For example, if you search four mailboxes and the search returns 1,500 estimated items, only 400 will be available for preview because only 100 items from each mailbox can be previewed."

We don't know how many messages we have as output. There is also no information that we should be able to preview the content of all messages. Sampling means previewing selected (randomly) messages (max 100 with one location). If it is less than 101 we can see all of them - there is only one mailbox. I think D might be appropriate.

comments.content: thx for feedback

Unless there's a technical reason for a question to be deprecated you always have to assume it's still relevant. Those comments make absolutely no sense and it'd be a crazy idea to prioritize because of them. Makes much more sense to mention in the discussion that and why a question seems outdated..
It means its still a relevant question in the exam question bank and hasn't been deprecated

You don't find out what questions you got right or wrong - you can guess but you don't know. They are giving a heads up about what was asked so you can perform due diligence when studying, which I find incredibly useful.
so I've seen this a few times from you. you just mention it was on the test but do not provide feedback on the answer. not much help to the rest of us.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com.
A user named User1 is a member of a dynamic group named Group1.
User1 reports that he cannot access documents shared to Group1.
You discover that User1 is no longer a member of Group1.
You suspect that an administrator made a change that caused User1 to be removed from Group1.
You need to identify which administrator made the change.
Which audit log activity should you search in the Security & Compliance admin center?

choices.A: Azure AD group administration activities ג€" Removed member from group
choices.C: Azure AD group administration activities ג€" Updated group
choices.B: User administration activities ג€" Updated user

discussion.content: Wouldn't this be B since Group1 is a dynamic group? Therefore user attribute should have been changed, otherwise user1 would be added back in the group automatically..

comments.content: Or the dynamic rule was changed and then answer C would be correct as this is a change of the group

B is the correct answer!
Security menu item from O365 Admin page -> Search menu from left panel -> choose User administration activities from Activities -> under that, choose "Updated user".

it got updated to 

https://compliance.microsoft.com/auditlogsearch

discussion.content: Finally got time to test this scenario out. I agree with Smoo. I can see two entries. One from the "Removed member from group". Which shows the user was removed but not who did it. On the Updated user entry, I can see the ID was updated/removed and the user that did it. You need to expand the entry to see more details under "ModifiedProperties". The answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
A. Can't be true since its a dynamic group and direct removal not possible
B. Most likely scenario as change of attribute on basis of which dynamic group membership was evaluated if changed by an admin then user would be out
C. Its still possible as one can change the group definition itself and new definition can be anything else to keep the user out but I would not chose this option in exam as if that's the case, many users would be impacted.

If multiple choice, then I would chose B & C and if single choice then B
mumbling about it I would say, if the query was changed, maybe more than one user would be removed so the "more" probable option is an user modification? but it's a speculation
it miss too much info, if the query was changed it's C (maybe it's a multiple and statement query and user miss one) or the user itself was changed and it doesn't match the query anymore.. who knows

Selected Answer: B
B since Group1 is a dynamic group
Just to really throw a wrench in all this...there is no "Security and Compliance" dashboard, there are two -- MS 365 Defender (Security) and Compliance. So old quesiton that isn't good anymore?

Selected Answer: B
Activity - Updated user, user=admin who changed, item=affected user, click for details, scroll to ModifiedProperties to see what was changed.
The next logged event for item (affected user) will be by "service principal_" activity = Removed member from group.
Answer is B 100% - I am auditing this for our compliance on a daily basis.

agree with some others - can be B or C that could cause this, but as F_M says I would think most likely they are looking for B as it only mentions 1 user being effected. Perfectly feasible of course that the rule could have been changed to effect just one user, but without full info we have to take a best guess here

comments.content:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/search-the-audit-log-in-security-and-compliance?view=o365-worldwide#audited-activities
Updated user --> Administrator changes one or more properties of a user account. For a list of the user properties that can be updated, see the "Update user attributes" section in Azure Active Directory Audit Report Events.

discussion.content:
C is the answer.

just test in my environment. no recrd in update user audit log but record to show i changed the query in the dynamic group in update group so that the user was excluded from the group membership.

I think both B and C can be valid answers.
By the way the question states that only one user can't access the group anymore so I would say that is more likely a change on the user properties. If the dynamic membership rule was change I expect that more than one user lost the access.
With this specific question wording and answer set, I would go with B.

Tested in my lab. The correct answer is B. An administrator performed a change on User 1 attributes and broke the match with dynamic group membership. This action is audit under "User administration activities - Updated user"
For me is not clear. I can update the query for the dynamic group. Bu I can also edit a user property, location as a sample and user i also out of group. But I think she mean answer B.

comments.content: As you stated, you don't understand what user attributes are or how a dynamic query works. All you have to do is change the attribute(s) of the user that the dynamic query keys off of to have that user fall out of the group. Only one user was impacted so it's not likely that the group was updated.

discussion.content:
C
A: This is a dynamic group, after you create the group, you cannot change it from a dynamic group to a static group, you must re-create the group. Hence, the only way to remove the member is to either change the query or the user attributes (whatever that is) that will add the user to the group. It all depends on the query.
B: While this can be an answer it cannot guarantee that the user is removed from the group. It all depends on how the group membership query is constructed which may or may not be based on the user attributes.
C: This is the only way that the user can be removed from the group which is by modifying the query itself.

I think answer C. This can help

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/search-the-audit-log-in-security-and-compliance?view=o365-worldwide#user-administration-activities
Part of the question states "You suspect that an administrator made a change that caused User1 to be removed from Group1" That is the key to which answer is correct. Therefore, I go with C.
B... When an attribute changes for a user or device, all dynamic group rules in the organization are processed for membership changes. Tested with an existing customer
I will go with B since it is dynamic group, admin needs to change user properties that will add/remove him from group where dynamic rule membership gets members in and out

Ambiguous question. Both B and C can be the answer. If admin changed a property on user1 that acts as a criteria of group membership then user gets removed from group1.
If admin made change to group1's membership criteria that excluded User1 then that will be the reason for user1's removal.
The answer is correct, the question says "you suspect the administrator made a change where would you check"

comments.content: It's a dynamic query so while the acitivity will be logged as you indicated it doesn't tell you who made the change to cause the user to fall out of the group, only that the user did indeed fall out of the group. A static group this would apply.
A is the right answer, I have tested in my Lab

discussion.content:
As per the document, the answer is A. 

Azure AD group administration activities
The following table lists group administration activities that are logged when an admin or a user creates or changes a Microsoft 365 group or when an admin creates a security group by using the Microsoft 365 admin center or the Azure management portal. For more information about groups in Office 365, see View, create, and delete Groups in the Microsoft 365 admin center.

AZURE AD GROUP ADMINISTRATION ACTIVITIES
Friendly name Operation Description
Added group Add group A group was created.
Added member to group Add member to group A member was added to a group.
Deleted group Delete group A group was deleted.
Removed member from group Remove member from group A member was removed from a group.
Updated group Update group A property of a group was changed.

Ref: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/search-the-audit-log-in-security-and-compliance?view=o365-worldwide#user-administration-activities

Just tested this by using a dynamic group. When the dynamic group gets updated and therefore "Removed member from group" it shows a Service Principal and not the admin who did it. 

If I search for "Updated Group" - I see the User who made the change but the Item is showing "Not Available" so doesn't show me the user was removed from the group

If I search "Updated User" it shows me the administrator who made the change to that user account.

IMO B is the closest since it shows me who made the change

comments.content: Yikes. I missed the dynamic group part.

The group is a dynamic group. You can't add or remove users to dynamic groups. You can change the varibles of the group that will cause User1 to be dynamically removed or change a variable of User1 to cause the account to be removed, though this is rather unlikely in standard deployments. So the answer is Azure AD group administration activities "" Updated group

discussion.content:
I think the answer is A. see below reference.
Azure AD group administration activities - Removed member from group - description - A member was removed from a group.

User administration activities "" Updated user - Description - Administrator changes one or more properties of a user account

Azure AD group administration activities "" Updated group - description - A property of a group was changed.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/search-the-audit-log-in-security-and-compliance?view=o365-worldwide

Provided answer is correct.
You can find similar question and answers on ms-500,q18 topic4.

Removed member from group: => shows the user that was removed 
(by modifying dynamic the query) 

Updated group: => shows what user 'updated' the group.

comments.content:
Updated group Update group A property of a group was changed.

Ref: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/search-the-audit-log-in-security-and-compliance?view=o365-worldwide#user-administration-activities

discussion.content: Both B and C could be valid according to me... depending on how he 'removed the user from the group. If he changed the Membership rule of the Dynamic group so that the user got excluded then C would be the correct search but if he changed a User attribute so that the User is no longer picked up by the Membership rule then B is the correct answer.
B. User administration activities "" Updated user

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
All users are assigned Microsoft Azure Active Directory Premium licenses.
From the Device Management admin center, you set Microsoft Intune as the MDM authority.
You need to ensure that when the members of a group named Marketing join a device to Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), the device is enrolled automatically in
Intune. The Marketing group members must be limited to five devices enrolled in Intune.
Which two options should you use to perform the configurations? To answer, select the appropriate blades in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Device enrollment manager (DEM) is an Intune permission that can be applied to an Azure AD user account and lets the user enroll up to 1,000 devices
You can create and manage enrollment restrictions that define what devices can enroll into management with Intune, including the:
✑ Number of devices.
✑ Operating systems and versions.
The Marketing group members must be limited to five devices enrolled in Intune
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/enrollment/device-enrollment-manager-enroll https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/enrollment/enrollment-restrictions-set

discussion.content: enrollment restrictions & windows enrollment; automatic

comments.content: i agree.

"Joined". Only Windows 10 devices can JOIN and Azure AD enviroment, therefore, giving them the capability for autoenrollment. 

Any other devices (iOS, Android) can only "Register" their devices in Azure AD, so they can't auto enroll. 

There's the Apple Device Enrollment Program for iOS where no Intune App needs to be installed, etc, but I believe the question would mention that specifically, so this is out of scope.
Whoops sorry you're right. I accidentally skipped over joining them to Azure AD, not registering.
Auto-enrolling is also a Windows 10 only feature.

Join is for user but "the device is enrolled automatically in
Intune"
It says "a device" not specified what sort of device. So choosing Windows enrollment wouldn't "assure" they could enroll an Ipad, for example.

discussion.content:
Auto-Enrollment is a Windows 10 only feature and in order to limit the devices we must use Enrollment Restrictions.

Enrollment restrictions & Windows Enrollment are the 2 only logical answers.
Windows Enrollment (for auto-enrollment &Windows devices joined to AD) and Enrollment restrictions (restrict the number of devices enrolled per user) are the only two logical answers.
